qas.question: Byte order marks are forbidden in protocols using what standard?
Why is it possible to distinguish UTF-8 from other protocols?

answers.text: the large restriction on possible patterns

plausible_answers.text: where the character set is unmarked

qas.question: BOM can not replace what kind of UTF-8 text?
What is used to distinguish local 8-bit code pages?
What is the name of the BOM standard?
What type of bytes are required in a high bit set?
What type of patterns are rarely resticted?

context: The same character converted to UTF-8 becomes the byte sequence EF BB BF. The Unicode Standard allows that the <b4_0>BOM<b4_0/> "can serve as signature for UTF-8 encoded text <b3_0>where the character set is unmarked<b3_0/>". Some software developers have adopted it for other encodings, including UTF-8, in an attempt to distinguish UTF-8 from local 8-bit code pages. However <a0_0><b5_0>RFC 3629<b5_0/><a0_0/>, the UTF-8 standard, recommends that byte order marks be forbidden in protocols using <a1_0>UTF-8<a1_0/>, but discusses the cases where this may not be possible. In addition, <a2_0>the large restriction on <b7_0>possible patterns<a2_0/> in UTF-8<b7_0/> (for instance there cannot be any <b6_0>lone<b6_0/> bytes with the high bit set) means that it should be possible to distinguish UTF-8 from other character encodings without relying on the BOM.
